title: How to Prevent Silverware from Tarnishing

steps.headline: Polish your silverware weekly if you’re able to.
steps.description: While it can be time-consuming, polishing the silverware every week is the best way to ensure it stays clean. Use a polish that’s made for silver since other polishes could cause pitting or leave small scratches. Apply a pea-sized dab of the polish to a soft cleaning rag or cotton ball, and move the silverware back and forth to apply it. Once you polish the silverware, rinse it under cold water and dry it completely. You can buy silver polish from jewelry stores or online. If your silverware has intricate details on it, then use a soft-bristled toothbrush to work the polish into the hard-to-reach areas. You can also use toothpaste in place of silver polish if you want. Don’t use a colored gel toothpaste since it may leave residue on your utensils.

steps.headline: Wash silverware with warm water and mild soap immediately after using it.
steps.description: Don’t leave silverware in the sink with food residue since the acids could cause the silver to discolor. Wipe the silverware clean with a soft washcloth or sponge soaked in warm soapy water. After you wash the silverware, dry it immediately since moisture left on the surface can make tarnish develop faster. Don’t let silverware soak in water for extended periods of time since it could also cause tarnish to form.Warning: Avoid putting silverware in the dishwasher since the detergent is usually abrasive and doesn’t clean as well as washing it by hand.

steps.headline: Keep white chalk in your silverware drawer to help absorb the moisture.
steps.description: White chalk reduces the amount of moisture and sulfur compounds that can cause tarnish. Wrap a few pieces of chalk in cheesecloth to prevent the dust from getting on other things in your silverware drawer. Replace the chalk once or twice per year to keep your silverware looking shiny. Store the chalk near the back of the drawer so it’s less likely to spill or get disturbed. Avoid using colored chalk since it may not be able to absorb as much moisture or sulfur. You can also use silica-gel beads to absorb the moisture in your drawer. You can buy silica beads online or from hobby stores.

steps.headline: Store silverware in an airtight container if there’s high humidity.
steps.description: Humid climates can cause your silverware to tarnish faster since there’s a lot of moisture in the air. If you live in an area with high humidity, wrap each of your utensils in tissue paper as tightly as you can. Then put your wrapped silverware in larger plastic containers with lids or resealable plastic bags. If you store your silverware in plastic bags, try to press out as much air from the bags before sealing them.

steps.headline: Wear cotton gloves when handling your silverware to keep oil off of them.
steps.description: Your skin has natural acids and oils that cause tarnish to form on your silverware. Whenever you need to take out your silverware to set the table or polish, wear your cotton gloves so you don’t transfer the oils. You don’t need to wear gloves while you’re eating since you’ll be washing the dishes afterward. Don’t wear latex gloves when handling silverware since the gloves may contain enough sulfur to tarnish your utensils.

steps.headline: Line a baking pan with aluminum foil.
steps.description: Pick a baking pan that’s large enough to hold all of your silverware at the same time. Use pieces of aluminum foil to completely cover the bottom and sides of the baking pan. Make sure that none of the pan shows through the foil or else the cleaning may not be as effective. Once you start cleaning, the aluminum reacts with the silver to remove the tarnish.

steps.headline: Combine white vinegar, baking soda, and salt in the bowl.
steps.description: Pour 1 tablespoon (17 g) of salt, 1 tablespoon (14.5 g) of baking soda, and ⁄2 cup (120 ml) of distilled white vinegar into the pan. Stir the mixture together until it forms a thick paste-like consistency. The vinegar and baking soda will form a reaction that helps lift the tarnish off the silver.

steps.headline: Fill the baking pan with boiling water.
steps.description: Boil water in another pot or a kettle so you have enough to completely submerge the silverware. Once the water’s boiling, pour it into the baking pan so it combines with the salt, baking soda, and vinegar.

steps.headline: Submerge your tarnished silverware for 30 seconds.
steps.description: Place all of your silverware in the baking pan so each of the utensils touches the aluminum foil. Leave the silverware alone in the pan for at least 30 seconds, and watch for the tarnish to come off of the utensils. After that, use a pair of tongs to grab the silverware out of the pan so you can finish cleaning them. Don’t stack the silverware on top of itself or else the tarnish may not come off. You can do a few utensils at a time if you don’t have space for all of them in the pan.Tip: It may take heavily-tarnished silverware up to 3-5 minutes for it to get completely clean.

steps.headline: Dry the silverware to get rid of any remaining tarnish.
steps.description: Use a soft clean towel to pat the silverware dry. Inspect each utensil and look for any tarnish that’s still on the surface. If there’s tarnish, rub the towel back and forth over the area to see if it comes off. If you still see tarnish, then put the silverware back in the pan to soak for another 30-60 seconds. Use a soft-bristled toothbrush to get tarnish out of hard-to-reach spots.

steps.headline: Polish your silverware before putting it away.
steps.description: Use polish that’s made specifically for silver or else you could damage your utensils. Dip a cotton ball or a cleaning rag into the polish and spread it over the piece of silverware. Work in back and forth strokes rather than in circles to prevent scratching. Once you polish the silverware, rinse it with water and dry it thoroughly to prevent tarnish. You can also use toothpaste if you don’t have any silver polish.
